seo.meta_title: Carter Dome Trail Guide | 2 Routes, Maps & Conditions

schema_place.name: Carter Dome
schema_place.description: Carter Dome is a 4,832 foot peak in New Hampshire offering hiking trails with scenic views.

mainEntity.name: How long does it take to hike Carter Dome?

acceptedAnswer.text: Most routes on Carter Dome take 5-7 hours round trip. The most popular trail is 10.0 miles with Hard difficulty. Start early, especially on weekends when parking fills quickly.

mainEntity.name: Is Carter Dome hard to hike?

acceptedAnswer.text: Carter Dome is rated Hard. At 4,832 feet, expect challenging terrain above treeline with potential for rapid weather changes. Proper footwear and preparation are essential.

mainEntity.name: Do I need a permit to hike Carter Dome?

acceptedAnswer.text: No hiking permit is required for Carter Dome. However, parking fees may apply at trailheads (typically $3-5/day for WMNF or state parks). A WMNF parking pass covers most White Mountain trailheads.

mainEntity.name: What is the best trail to hike Carter Dome?

acceptedAnswer.text: The most popular route is the Nineteen Mile Brook Trail, offering Route via Carter Notch Hut to Carter Dome summit..

mainEntity.name: When is the best time to hike Carter Dome?

acceptedAnswer.text: The best hiking season for Carter Dome is late May through October. Summer and fall offer the best conditions, though expect crowds on weekends. Winter hiking requires specialized gear and experience.

page_content.description:
At 4,832 feet, Carter Dome ranks among New Hampshire's celebrated 4000-Footers—a collection of 48 peaks that challenge and inspire hikers throughout the Northeast. This hard summit offers a quintessential White Mountain experience.

Popular Routes

The most popular route, **Nineteen Mile Brook Trail**, covers 10.0 miles and is rated Hard. Route via Carter Notch Hut to Carter Dome summit.

Peak Bagging

**Extend Your Adventure:** Wildcat A lies just 1.3 miles away, making it an excellent addition for ambitious hikers looking to bag multiple summits.

spring.title: Spring Conditions
spring.conditions: Muddy trails, snow above 3000ft until May
spring.tips: Trail closures for mud season (April-May). Check conditions before heading out.

summer.title: Summer Conditions
summer.tips: Start early to avoid afternoon storms and parking issues. Peak crowds on weekends.

fall.title: Fall Conditions
fall.conditions: Peak foliage late Sept, early snow possible in October
fall.tips: Peak foliage brings peak crowds. Weekday hikes recommended. Watch for ice above treeline in late October.

winter.title: Winter Conditions
winter.conditions: Full winter conditions, extreme cold and wind above treeline
winter.tips: Winter hiking requires specialized skills and gear. Never hike alone. Check avalanche conditions for steeper terrain.

current_hazards: ⚠️ ALPINE ZONE: Weather changes rapidly. Turn back if conditions deteriorate.
Winter conditions in effect - full mountaineering gear required
Hypothermia risk - temperatures 20-40°F colder at summit
Trail markers may be buried under snow
